thread.title: Denver school board election gets less attention, but still critical
thread.title_full: Denver school board election gets less attention, but still critical - The Denver Post

author: Yesenia Robles
title: Denver school board election gets less attention, but still critical
text:
In an election year not poised to change the majority of the Denver Public Schools board of education, some say the changes the district has been implementing still face a test.
"The school board now is probably more interesting than it has ever been," said Van Schoales, chief executive officer for nonprofit A-Plus Denver. "The board is actually driving some policy decisions instead of either being about we support the district or we don't. Whomever the new board members are going to be, they will be able to shape policy. That has not been the case for some time."
Incumbents Anne Rowe and Allegra "Happy" Haynes say the district still has work to do in getting more high-quality schools in every neighborhood, but their opponents, Kristi Butkovich and Robert Speth, say the district is not heading in the right direction and may be making things worse.
"The district's achievement gap is almost doubling. It's going the wrong direction really fast," said Speth, who is challenging Haynes for her at-large seat. "It would be a wake-up call. It's about hearing what the communities want. I may get shot down, but the points will be put forth."
Board candidates supported by the teachers union, Speth, But kovich and Michael Kiley in northwest Denver, have raised more money so far. But overall, candidates have raised less than half of what was reported by this time in 2013 or 2011.
Advertisement Reform groups have not been as active in contributions to candidates, but a local committee, Raising Colorado, associated with Democrats for Education Reform, did report $250,000 in contributions from the New York group Education Reform Now.
In some ways, the issues most discussed remain familiar. Much discussion has focused on pitting support for traditional neighborhood schools against support for charter schools.
In northwest Denver's race, where Kiley is running against Lisa Flores, Kiley says he doesn't oppose charter schools, but opposed the idea of having one be a neighborhood school instead of a choice. Flores says some charters are the highest achieving in the district and shouldn't be demonized, but said all schools need to be better.
Most candidates also say they want to address the high turnover of principals and teachers, and some criticize how the district has handled it so far.
Other district initiatives that have been criticized include the creation of enrollment zones , and co-locating schools within buildings, including one at Lincoln High School .
The board elected Nov. 3 will oversee the continuing implementation of the district's master plan to have at least 80 percent of students in each neighborhood in high- performing schools. The district is also renegotiating ProComp, the district's pay for performance plan and trying out changes to give schools more flexibility.
"My colleagues and I have worked really hard in the creation of the Denver Plan 2020 to ensure that every child has access to a high-quality school," Rowe said. "I think this year's election for the school board is incredibly important."

Dps board of education candidates
District 1:
Kristi Butkovich executive director of the Denver Alliance for Public Education
Money raised: $29,256.42
Largest donors: DCTA Fund, $21,000; Kristi Butkovich, $1,350.
Top priorities: Putting kids first. Hiring and retaining quality teachers. Earning back the community's trust.
Support performance pay: No
Support providing facilities for charter schools: No
Support enrollment zones: Yes, if driven by communities.
Anne Rowe current board member
Money raised: $18,880 Largest donors: Dan Ritchie, $2,500; Eric Black, $1,000; David Younggren, $1,000.
Top priorities: Investing in leadership. School flexibility. Early literacy.
Support performance pay: Yes
Support providing facilities for charter schools: Yes
Support enrollment zones: Yes
District 5:
Lisa Flores most recently program officer for Gates Family Foundation
Money raised: $79,639Largest donors: $5,000 each from Walter Kirkham, Rick Tallman, Phillip Reyes.
Top priorities: Principal and teacher leadership. Achievement gap. Early childhood education.
Support performance pay: Yes
Support providing facilities for charter schools: Yes
Support enrollment zones: Yes
Michael Kiley software project manager for Kronos
Money raised: $55,869 Largest donors:DCTA Fund, $38,000; Rene Renteria, $1,500.
Top priorities: Supporting principals and teachers, and reducing turnover rates. Neighborhood schools.
Support performance pay: Yes.
Support providing facilities for charter schools: Yes, only in vacated buildings.
Support enrollment zones: No
At-large candidates:
Allegra "Happy" Haynes current board member, director of the Denver Department of Parks and Recreation
Money raised: $16,555 Largest donors: Edgar Benton, $1,500; $1,000 each from James Hannifin and David Younggren.
Top priorities: Closing the opportunity gap. Principal and teacher leadership. Early literacy. Increased flexibility for schools.
Support performance pay: Yes
Support providing facilities for charter schools: Yes
Support enrollment zones: Yes
Robert Speth senior strategic account manager for Sprint
Money raised: $40,650Largest donors: DCTA Fund, $25,000; Robert Speth, $2,500.
Top priorities: Community teamwork. Teacher retention. Less testing.
Support performance pay: Yes, if tests are weighed less.
Support providing facilities for charter schools: No, unless building is empty.
Support enrollment zones: Yes, if it includes more than one traditional neighborhood school.
